message.content: We refer to the formula for specificity: Specificity = true negatives / (true negatives + false positives). From the table, we can see that there are 35 true negatives and 15 false positives. Therefore, specificity = 35 / (35 + 15) = 70%.

We can use the formula for specificity: true negatives / (true negatives + false positives) x 100. In this case, the true negatives are 35 and the false positives are 15, so the specificity is 35 / (35 + 15) x 100 = 70%. This means that the test correctly identifies 70% of the individuals who do not have ASD as not having the disorder.

We refer to the formula for specificity: True negative / (True negative + False positive). In this case, there were 35 true negatives and 15 false positives, so the specificity is 35 / (35 + 15) = 70%.

We refer to MedlinePlus website for help. Specificity is the proportion of individuals without the condition who have a negative test result. Thus, specificity equals the number of true negatives (35) divided by the total number of individuals without the disorder (50), which equals 0.7 or 70%.

We calculate specificity as the proportion of true negatives (TN) out of the total number of non-diseased individuals (TN + FP), where FP is false positives. In this case, there are 35 true negatives and 15 false positives, so specificity = TN / (TN + FP) = 35 / (35 + 15) = 0.7 or 70%. Therefore, the correct answer is (C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Specificity is the proportion of true negatives to the total number of people without the disease. In this case, there are 50 children without ASD, and 35 of them tested negative, giving a specificity of 70% (35/50). The test has a high false positive rate (45/50 with ASD tested positive) and a low positive predictive value.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Specificity is defined as the proportion of true negatives among all negatives. In this case, the true negatives are the children without the disorder who test negative, which is 35. Therefore, the specificity is 35/(35+15) = 70%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Specificity is the proportion of true negatives (children without the disorder who tested negative), which is calculated by dividing the number of true negatives by the total number of children without the disorder who were tested negative. In this case, the number of true negatives is 35 and the total number of children without the disorder who were tested negative is 50, so the specificity is 35/50 = 0.7, or 70%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Specificity is defined as the proportion of individuals without the disorder who have a negative test result. Out of 50 children without ASD, 35 had a negative test result, thus the specificity is 35/50 or 70%.

We use the formula for specificity: true negatives / (true negatives + false positives) x 100%. In this case, there were 35 true negatives and 15 false positives, so specificity is 35 / (35 + 15) x 100% = 70%. The test correctly identified 70% of individuals without ASD as not having the disorder.
